title: The real reason Nigel Owens wasn't picked to referee England v South Africa final
text:
The Welshman was bidding to referee his second consecutive final (Picture: Getty)

Nigel Owens was overlooked to referee the Rugby World Cup final after picking up a calf injury, with Jerome Garces selected to officiate Saturday’s showpiece between England and South Africa instead.

The Welsh ref was bidding to take charge of his second consecutive final, having officiated the 2015 clash between New Zealand and Australia at Twickenham.

He was in the running to be given the job again in Yokohama on Saturday, but, according to The Telegraph, ruled himself out after pulling his calf muscle.

Garces, left, will be accopanied by compatriot Roman Poite, right, in the final (Picture: Getty)

Owens is understood to have picked up the injury in the first half of last weekend’s semi-final between England and New Zealand but managed to get through the game after receiving treatment.

He will not be fit for the final, however, with Garces becoming the first Frenchman to referee the tournament’s showpiece instead.

There have been suggestions that Garces would have been awarded the final even if Owens had not got injured, though he could still have played a role as an assistant.

Instead, Garces will be joined by compatriot Romain Poite and New Zealand’s Ben O’Keeffe, while another Kiwi, Ben Skeen, is the television match official.

Speaking about his appointment for the final, Garces said: ‘I am honoured and delighted to be appointed to referee the Rugby World Cup 2019 final.

England progressed to the final with a dominant win over champions New Zealand (Picture: Getty)

‘It is a dream as a referee, but this is a team sport, and as a team of four, we will be out there to do the best for the teams, the fans, the sport, but also the entire match officials team, selectors and support team, who have worked so hard over the last four years, culminating in Rugby World Cup 2019.’

England’s Wayne Barnes, the pre-tournament favourite to take the final before the Red Roses’ heroic run, will take charge of the third-place play-off in Tokyo between New Zealand and Wales on Friday.
